# Cerebrospinal fluid

From Wikipedia, the free encyclopedia

Jump to navigation Jump to search

This article uses anatomical terminology; for an overview, see [Anatomical
terminology](/wiki/Anatomical_terminology "Anatomical terminology").

_Cerebrospinal fluid_  
---

**Cerebrospinal fluid** (**CSF**) is a clear, colorless [body
fluid](/wiki/Body_fluid "Body fluid") found in the [brain](/wiki/Human_brain
"Human brain") and [spinal cord](/wiki/Spinal_cord "Spinal cord"). It is
produced by the specialised ependymal cells in the [choroid
plexuses](/wiki/Choroid_plexus "Choroid plexus") of the
[ventricles](/wiki/Ventricular_system "Ventricular system") of the brain, and
absorbed in the [arachnoid granulations](/wiki/Arachnoid_granulation
"Arachnoid granulation"). There is about 125mL of CSF at any one time, and
about 500mL is generated every day. CSF acts as a cushion or buffer for the
brain, providing basic mechanical and [immunological](/wiki/Immunological
"Immunological") protection to the brain inside the [skull](/wiki/Human_skull
"Human skull"). CSF also serves a vital function in [cerebral
autoregulation](/wiki/Cerebral_autoregulation "Cerebral autoregulation") of
[cerebral blood flow](/wiki/Cerebral_blood_flow "Cerebral blood flow").

CSF occupies the [subarachnoid space](/wiki/Subarachnoid_space "Subarachnoid
space") (between the [arachnoid mater](/wiki/Arachnoid_mater "Arachnoid
mater") and the [pia mater](/wiki/Pia_mater "Pia mater")) and the [ventricular
system](/wiki/Ventricular_system "Ventricular system") around and inside the
brain and spinal cord. It fills the [ventricles](/wiki/Ventricular_system
"Ventricular system") of the brain, [cisterns](/wiki/Subarachnoid_cisterns
"Subarachnoid cisterns"), and [sulci](/wiki/Sulcus_\(neuroanatomy\) "Sulcus
\(neuroanatomy\)"), as well as the [central canal](/wiki/Central_canal
"Central canal") of the spinal cord. There is also a connection from the
subarachnoid space to the [bony labyrinth](/wiki/Bony_labyrinth "Bony
labyrinth") of the [inner ear](/wiki/Inner_ear "Inner ear") via the
[perilymphatic duct](/wiki/Perilymphatic_duct "Perilymphatic duct") where the
[perilymph](/wiki/Perilymph "Perilymph") is continuous with the cerebrospinal
fluid.

A sample of CSF can be taken via [lumbar puncture](/wiki/Lumbar_puncture
"Lumbar puncture"). This can reveal the [intracranial
pressure](/wiki/Intracranial_pressure "Intracranial pressure"), as well as
indicate diseases including [infections of the brain](/wiki/Encephalitis
"Encephalitis") or [its surrounding meninges](/wiki/Meningitis "Meningitis").
Although noted by [Hippocrates](/wiki/Hippocrates "Hippocrates"), it was only
in the 18th century that [Emanuel Swedenborg](/wiki/Emanuel_Swedenborg
"Emanuel Swedenborg") is credited with its rediscovery, and as late as 1914
that [Harvey W. Cushing](/wiki/Harvey_W._Cushing "Harvey W. Cushing")
demonstrated CSF was secreted by the choroid plexus.

##
Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Structure")]

###
Circulation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Circulation")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/38/NPH_MRI_272_GILD.gif/220px-
NPH_MRI_272_GILD.gif)](/wiki/File:NPH_MRI_272_GILD.gif)

[](/wiki/File:NPH_MRI_272_GILD.gif "Enlarge")

MRI showing pulsation of CSF

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/c3/Dist_vent.png/350px-
Dist_vent.png)](/wiki/File:Dist_vent.png)

[](/wiki/File:Dist_vent.png "Enlarge")

Distribution of CSF

There is about 125-150 mL of CSF at any one time.[1] This CSF circulates
within the [ventricular system](/wiki/Ventricular_system "Ventricular system")
of the brain. The ventricles are a series of cavities filled with CSF. The
majority of CSF is produced from within the two [lateral
ventricles](/wiki/Lateral_ventricles "Lateral ventricles"). From here, CSF
passes through the [interventricular
foramina](/wiki/Interventricular_foramina_\(neuroanatomy\) "Interventricular
foramina \(neuroanatomy\)") to the [third ventricle](/wiki/Third_ventricle
"Third ventricle"), then the [cerebral aqueduct](/wiki/Cerebral_aqueduct
"Cerebral aqueduct") to the [fourth ventricle](/wiki/Fourth_ventricle "Fourth
ventricle"). From the fourth ventricle, the fluid passes into the
[subarachnoid space](/wiki/Subarachnoid_space "Subarachnoid space") through
four openings – the [central canal](/wiki/Central_canal "Central canal") of
the spinal cord, the [median aperture](/wiki/Median_aperture "Median
aperture"), and the two [lateral apertures](/wiki/Lateral_aperture "Lateral
aperture").[1] CSF is present within the subarachnoid space, which covers the
brain, spinal cord, and stretches below the end of the spinal cord to the
[sacrum](/wiki/Sacrum "Sacrum").[1][2] There is a connection from the
subarachnoid space to the [bony labyrinth](/wiki/Bony_labyrinth "Bony
labyrinth") of the [inner ear](/wiki/Inner_ear "Inner ear") making the
cerebrospinal fluid continuous with the [perilymph](/wiki/Perilymph
"Perilymph") in 93% of people.[3]

CSF moves in a single outward direction from the ventricles, but
multidirectionally in the subarachnoid space.[3] Fluid movement is pulsatile,
matching the pressure waves generated in blood vessels by the beating of the
heart.[3] Some authors dispute this, posing that there is no unidirectional
CSF circulation, but cardiac cycle-dependent bi-directional systolic-diastolic
to-and-fro cranio-spinal CSF movements.[4]

###
Contents[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=3
"Edit section: Contents")]

CSF is derived from [blood plasma](/wiki/Blood_plasma "Blood plasma") and is
largely similar to it, except that CSF is nearly protein-free compared with
plasma and has some different [electrolyte](/wiki/Electrolyte "Electrolyte")
levels. Due to the way it is produced, CSF has a higher
[chloride](/wiki/Chloride "Chloride") level than plasma, and an equivalent
[sodium](/wiki/Sodium "Sodium") level.[2][5]

CSF contains approximately 0.3% plasma proteins, or approximately 15 to 40
mg/dL, depending on sampling site.[6] In general, globular proteins and
albumin are in lower concentration in ventricular CSF compared to lumbar or
cisternal fluid.[7] This continuous flow into the [venous
system](/wiki/Venous_system "Venous system") dilutes the concentration of
larger, lipid-insoluble molecules penetrating the brain and CSF.[8] CSF is
normally free of [red blood cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red blood cell"), and
at most contains only a few [white blood cells](/wiki/White_blood_cell "White
blood cell"). Any white blood [cell count](/wiki/Cell_counting "Cell
counting") higher than this constitutes [pleocytosis](/wiki/Pleocytosis
"Pleocytosis").[9]

##
Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Development")]

At around the third week of [development](/wiki/Human_embryogenesis "Human
embryogenesis"), the [embryo](/wiki/Embryo "Embryo") is a three-layered disc,
covered with [ectoderm](/wiki/Ectoderm "Ectoderm"), [mesoderm](/wiki/Mesoderm
"Mesoderm") and [endoderm](/wiki/Endoderm "Endoderm"). A tube-like formation
develops in the midline, called the [notochord](/wiki/Notochord "Notochord").
The notochord releases extracellular molecules that affect the transformation
of the overlying ectoderm into nervous tissue.[10] The [neural
tube](/wiki/Neural_tube "Neural tube"), forming from the ectoderm, contains
CSF prior to the development of the choroid plexuses.[3] The open
[neuropores](/wiki/Neuropore "Neuropore") of the neural tube close after the
first month of development, and CSF pressure gradually increases.[3]

As the [brain develops](/wiki/Brain#Development "Brain"), by the fourth week
of embryological development three swellings have formed within the embryo
around the canal, near where the head will develop. These swellings represent
different components of the [central nervous
system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system "Central nervous system"): the
[prosencephalon](/wiki/Prosencephalon "Prosencephalon"),
[mesencephalon](/wiki/Mesencephalon "Mesencephalon") and
[rhombencephalon](/wiki/Rhombencephalon "Rhombencephalon").[10] Subarachnoid
spaces are first evident around the 32nd day of development near the
rhombencephalon; circulation is visible from the 41st day.[3] At this time,
the first choroid plexus can be seen, found in the fourth ventricle, although
the time at which they first secrete CSF is not yet known.[3]

The developing forebrain surrounds the neural cord. As the forebrain develops,
the neural cord within it becomes a ventricle, ultimately forming the lateral
ventricles. Along the inner surface of both ventricles, the ventricular wall
remains thin, and a [choroid plexus](/wiki/Choroid_plexus "Choroid plexus")
develops, producing and releasing CSF.[10] CSF quickly fills the neural
canal.[10] Arachnoid villi are formed around the 35th week of development,
with aracnhoid granulations noted around the 39th, and continuing developing
until 18 months of age.[3]

The [subcommissural organ](/wiki/Subcommissural_organ "Subcommissural organ")
secretes [SCO-spondin](/wiki/SCO-spondin "SCO-spondin"), which forms
[Reissner's fiber](/wiki/Reissner%27s_fiber "Reissner's fiber") within CSF
assisting movement through the cerebral aqueduct. It is present in early
intra-uterine life but disappears during early development.[3]

##
Physiology[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=5
"Edit section: Physiology")]

###
Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Function")]

CSF serves several purposes:

  1. **Buoyancy:** The actual [mass](/wiki/Mass "Mass") of the [human brain](/wiki/Human_brain "Human brain") is about 1400–1500 grams; however, the net [weight](/wiki/Weight "Weight") of the brain suspended in CSF is equivalent to a mass of 25-50 grams.[11][1] The brain therefore exists in [neutral buoyancy](/wiki/Neutral_buoyancy "Neutral buoyancy"), which allows the brain to maintain its [density](/wiki/Density "Density") without being impaired by its own weight, which would cut off blood supply and kill [neurons](/wiki/Neuron "Neuron") in the lower sections without CSF.[5]
  2. **Protection:** CSF protects the brain tissue from injury when jolted or hit, by providing a fluid buffer that acts as a [shock absorber](/wiki/Shock_absorber "Shock absorber") from some forms of mechanical injury.[1][5]
  3. **Prevention of brain[ischemia](/wiki/Ischemia "Ischemia"):** The prevention of brain ischemia is made by decreasing the amount of CSF in the limited space inside the skull. This decreases total [intracranial pressure](/wiki/Intracranial_pressure "Intracranial pressure") and facilitates blood [perfusion](/wiki/Perfusion "Perfusion").[1]
  4. **[Homeostasis](/wiki/Homeostasis "Homeostasis"):** CSF allows for regulation of the distribution of substances between cells of the brain,[3] and [neuroendocrine](/wiki/Neuroendocrine "Neuroendocrine") factors, to which slight changes can cause problems or damage to the nervous system. For example, high [glycine](/wiki/Glycine "Glycine") [concentration](/wiki/Concentration "Concentration") disrupts [temperature](/wiki/Temperature "Temperature") and [blood pressure](/wiki/Blood_pressure "Blood pressure") control, and high CSF [pH](/wiki/PH "PH") causes [dizziness](/wiki/Dizziness "Dizziness") and [syncope](/wiki/Syncope_\(medicine\) "Syncope \(medicine\)").[5]
  5. **Clearing waste:** CSF allows for the removal of waste products from the brain,[1] and is critical in the brain's [lymphatic system](/wiki/Lymphatic_system "Lymphatic system").[12] Metabolic waste products [diffuse](/wiki/Diffusion "Diffusion") rapidly into CSF and are removed into the bloodstream as CSF is absorbed.[13]

###
Production[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Production")]

Comparison of Average Serum and Cerebrospinal Fluid  Substance | CSF | Serum   
---|---|---  
Water Content (%) | 99 | 93   
Protein (mg/dL) | 35 | 7000   
Glucose (mg/dL) | 60 | 90   
Osmolarity (mOsm/L) | 295 | 295   
[Sodium](/wiki/Sodium "Sodium") (mEq/L) | 138 | 138   
[Potassium](/wiki/Potassium "Potassium") (mEq/L) | 2.8 | 4.5   
[Calcium](/wiki/Calcium "Calcium") (mEq/L) | 2.1 | 4.8   
[Magnesium](/wiki/Magnesium "Magnesium") (mEq/L) | 2.0–2.5[14] | 1.7   
[Chloride](/wiki/Chloride "Chloride") (mEq/L) | 119 | 102   
pH | 7.33 | 7.41   
  
The brain produces roughly 500 mL of cerebrospinal fluid per day,[2] at a rate
of about 25 mL an hour.[1] This [transcellular
fluid](/wiki/Transcellular_fluid "Transcellular fluid") is constantly
reabsorbed, so that only 125–150 mL is present at any one time.[1]

CSF volume is higher on a mL/kg basis in children compared to adults. Infants
have a CSF volume of 4 mL/kg, children have a CSF volume of 3 mL/kg, and
adults have a CSF volume of 1.5-2 mL/kg. A high CSF volume is why a larger
dose of local anesthetic, on a mL/kg basis, is needed in infants.
Additionally, the larger CSF volume may be one reason as to why children have
lower rates of postdural puncture headache.[15]

Most (about two-thirds to 80%) of CSF is produced by the [choroid
plexus](/wiki/Choroid_plexus "Choroid plexus").[1][2] The choroid plexus is a
network of blood vessels present within sections of the [four
ventricles](/wiki/Ventricular_system "Ventricular system") of the brain. It is
present throughout the [ventricular system](/wiki/Ventricular_system
"Ventricular system") except for the [cerebral
aqueduct](/wiki/Cerebral_aqueduct "Cerebral aqueduct"), frontal horn of the
lateral ventricle, and occipital horn of the lateral ventricle.[16] CSF is
also produced by the [single layer of column-
shaped](/wiki/Simple_columnar_epithelium "Simple columnar epithelium")
[ependymal cells](/wiki/Ependymal_cell "Ependymal cell") which line the
ventricles; by the lining surrounding the [subarachnoid
space](/wiki/Subarachnoid_space "Subarachnoid space"); and a small amount
directly from the [tiny spaces surrounding blood
vessels](/wiki/Perivascular_space "Perivascular space") around the brain.[2]

CSF is produced by the choroid plexus in two steps. Firstly, a filtered form
of [plasma](/wiki/Blood_plasma "Blood plasma") moves from [fenestrated
capillaries](/wiki/Capillary#Fenestrated "Capillary") in the choroid plexus
into an interstitial space,[1] with movement guided by a difference in
pressure between the blood in the capillaries and the interstitial fluid.[3]
This fluid then needs to pass through the [epithelium](/wiki/Epithelium
"Epithelium") cells lining the choroid plexus into the ventricles, an active
process requiring the transport of [sodium](/wiki/Sodium "Sodium"),
[potassium](/wiki/Potassium "Potassium") and [chloride](/wiki/Chloride
"Chloride") that draws water into CSF by creating [osmotic
pressure](/wiki/Osmotic_pressure "Osmotic pressure").[3] Unlike blood passing
from the capillaries into the choroid plexus, the epithelial cells lining the
choroid plexus contain [tight junctions](/wiki/Tight_junctions "Tight
junctions") between cells, which act to prevent most substances flowing freely
into CSF.[17]

[Water](/wiki/Water "Water") and [carbon dioxide](/wiki/Carbon_dioxide "Carbon
dioxide") from the interstitial fluid diffuse into the epithelial cells.
Within these cells, [carbonic anhydrase](/wiki/Carbonic_anhydrase "Carbonic
anhydrase") converts the substances into [bicarbonate](/wiki/Bicarbonate
"Bicarbonate") and [hydrogen ions](/wiki/Hydrogen_ions "Hydrogen ions"). These
are exchanged for [sodium](/wiki/Sodium "Sodium") and
[chloride](/wiki/Chloride "Chloride") on the cell surface facing the
interstitium.[3] Sodium, chloride, bicarbonate and potassium are then actively
secreted into the ventricular lumen.[2][3] This creates [osmotic
pressure](/wiki/Osmotic_pressure "Osmotic pressure") and draws water into
CSF,[2] facilitated by [aquaporins](/wiki/Aquaporin "Aquaporin").[3]
[Chloride](/wiki/Chloride "Chloride"), with a negative charge, moves with the
positively charged sodium, to maintain
[electroneutrality](/wiki/Pauling%27s_principle_of_electroneutrality
"Pauling's principle of electroneutrality").[2] Potassium and bicarbonate are
also transported out of CSF.[2] As a result, CSF contains a higher
concentration of sodium and chloride than blood plasma, but less potassium,
calcium and glucose and protein.[5] Choroid plexuses also secrete growth
factors, [vitamins B1](/wiki/Vitamin_B1 "Vitamin B1"), [12](/wiki/Vitamin_B12
"Vitamin B12") [C](/wiki/Vitamin_C "Vitamin C"), [folate](/wiki/Folate
"Folate"), [beta-2 microglobulin](/wiki/Beta-2_microglobulin "Beta-2
microglobulin"), [arginine vasopressin](/wiki/Arginine_vasopressin "Arginine
vasopressin") and [nitrous oxide](/wiki/Nitrous_oxide "Nitrous oxide") into
CSF.[3] A [Na-K-Cl cotransporter](/wiki/Na-K-Cl_cotransporter "Na-K-Cl
cotransporter") and [Na/K ATPase](/wiki/Na/K_ATPase "Na/K ATPase") found on
the surface of the choroid endothelium, appears to play a role in regulating
CSF secretion and composition.[3][1]

Orešković and Klarica hypothesise that CSF is not primarily produced by the
choroid plexus, but is being permanently produced inside the entire CSF
system, as a consequence of water filtration through the capillary walls into
the interstitial fluid of the surrounding brain tissue, regulated by
[AQP-4](/wiki/Aquaporin_4 "Aquaporin 4").[4]

There are circadian variations in CSF secretion, with the mechanisms not fully
understood, but potentially relating to differences in the activation of the
[autonomic nervous system](/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system "Autonomic nervous
system") over the course of the day.[3]

Choroid plexus of the lateral ventricle produces CSF from the arterial blood
provided by the [choroidal arteries](/wiki/Choroidal_artery_\(disambiguation\)
"Choroidal artery \(disambiguation\)").[18] In the fourth ventricle, CSF is
produced from the artierial blood from the [anterior inferior cerebellar
artery](/wiki/Anterior_inferior_cerebellar_artery "Anterior inferior
cerebellar artery") (cerebellopontine angle and the adjacent part of the
lateral recess), the [posterior inferior cerebellar
artery](/wiki/Posterior_inferior_cerebellar_artery "Posterior inferior
cerebellar artery") (roof and median opening), and the [superior cerebellar
artery](/wiki/Superior_cerebellar_artery "Superior cerebellar artery").[19]

###
Reabsorption[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Reabsorption")]

CSF returns to the vascular system by entering the [dural venous
sinuses](/wiki/Dural_venous_sinuses "Dural venous sinuses") via [arachnoid
granulations](/wiki/Arachnoid_granulation "Arachnoid granulation").[2] These
are outpouchings of the [arachnoid mater](/wiki/Arachnoid_mater "Arachnoid
mater") into the venous sinuses around the brain, with valves to ensure one-
way drainage.[2] This occurs because of a pressure difference between the
arachnoid mater and venous sinuses.[3] CSF has also been seen to drain into
[lymphatic](/wiki/Lymph "Lymph") vessels,[20] particularly those surrounding
the nose via drainage along the [olfactory nerve](/wiki/Olfactory_nerve
"Olfactory nerve") through the [cribriform plate](/wiki/Cribriform_plate
"Cribriform plate"). The pathway and extent are currently not known,[1] but
may involve CSF flow along some cranial nerves and be more prominent in the
[neonate](/wiki/Neonate "Neonate").[3] CSF turns over at a rate of three to
four times a day.[2] CSF has also been seen to be reabsorbed through the
sheathes of [cranial](/wiki/Cranial_nerves "Cranial nerves") and [spinal
nerve](/wiki/Spinal_nerve "Spinal nerve") sheathes, and through the
ependyma.[3]

###
Regulation[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=9
"Edit section: Regulation")]

The composition and rate of CSF generation are influenced by hormones and the
content and pressure of blood and CSF.[3] For example, when CSF pressure is
higher, there is less of a pressure difference between the capillary blood in
choroid plexuses and CSF, decreasing the rate at which fluids move into the
choroid plexus and CSF generation.[3] The [autonomic nervous
system](/wiki/Autonomic_nervous_system "Autonomic nervous system") influences
choroid plexus CSF secretion, with activation of the [sympathetic nervous
system](/wiki/Sympathetic_nervous_system "Sympathetic nervous system")
increasing secretion and the [parasympathetic nervous
system](/wiki/Parasympathetic_nervous_system "Parasympathetic nervous system")
decreasing it.[3] Changes in the [pH](/wiki/PH "PH") of the blood can affect
the activity of carbonic anhydrase, and some drugs (such as
[frusemide](/wiki/Frusemide "Frusemide"), acting on the Na-K-Cl cotransporter)
have the potential to impact membrane channels.[3]

## Clinical
significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=10
"Edit section: Clinical significance")]

###
Pressure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=11
"Edit section: Pressure")]

CSF pressure, as measured by [lumbar puncture](/wiki/Lumbar_puncture "Lumbar
puncture"), is 10–18 [cmH2O](/wiki/Centimetre_of_water "Centimetre of water")
(8–15 [mmHg](/wiki/MmHg "MmHg") or 1.1–2 [kPa](/wiki/Kilopascal "Kilopascal"))
with the patient lying on the side and 20–30 cmH2O (16–24 mmHg or 2.1–3.2 kPa)
with the patient sitting up.[21] In newborns, CSF pressure ranges from 8 to 10
[cmH2O](/wiki/Centimetre_of_water "Centimetre of water") (4.4–7.3 mmHg or
0.78–0.98 kPa). Most variations are due to coughing or internal compression of
[jugular veins](/wiki/Jugular_vein "Jugular vein") in the neck. When lying
down, the CSF pressure as estimated by lumbar puncture is similar to the
[intracranial pressure](/wiki/Intracranial_pressure "Intracranial pressure").

[Hydrocephalus](/wiki/Hydrocephalus "Hydrocephalus") is an abnormal
accumulation of CSF in the ventricles of the brain.[22] Hydrocephalus can
occur because of [obstruction](/wiki/Obstructive_hydrocephalus "Obstructive
hydrocephalus") of the passage of CSF, such as from an infection, injury,
mass, or congenital abnormality.[22][23] Hydrocephalus without obstruction
associated with [normal CSF pressure](/wiki/Normal_pressure_hydrocephalus
"Normal pressure hydrocephalus") may also occur.[22] Symptoms can include
problems with [gait](/wiki/Gait "Gait") and
[coordination](/wiki/Motor_coordination "Motor coordination"), [urinary
incontinence](/wiki/Urinary_incontinence "Urinary incontinence"),
[nausea](/wiki/Nausea "Nausea") and vomiting, and progressively impaired
thinking.[23] In infants, hydrocephalus can cause an enlarged head, as the
bones of the skull have not yet fused, seizures, irritability and
drowsiness.[23] A [CT scan](/wiki/CT_scan "CT scan") or [MRI
scan](/wiki/MRI_scan "MRI scan") may reveal enlargement of one or both lateral
ventricles, or causative masses or lesions,[22][23] and lumbar puncture may be
used to demonstrate and in some circumstances relieve high intracranial
pressure.[24] Hydrocephalus is usually treated through the insertion of a
shunt, which diverts fluid to another part of the body, such as a [ventriculo-
peritoneal shunt](/wiki/Ventriculo-peritoneal_shunt "Ventriculo-peritoneal
shunt").[22][23]

[Idiopathic intracranial
hypertension](/wiki/Idiopathic_intracranial_hypertension "Idiopathic
intracranial hypertension") is a condition of unknown cause characterised by a
rise in CSF pressure. It is associated with headaches, [double
vision](/wiki/Double_vision "Double vision"), difficulties seeing, and a
[swollen optic disc](/wiki/Papilledema "Papilledema").[22] It can occur in
association with the use of Vitamin A and [tetracycline](/wiki/Tetracycline
"Tetracycline") antibiotics, or without any identifiable cause at all,
particularly in younger [obese](/wiki/Obese "Obese") women.[22] Management may
include ceasing any known causes, a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor such as
[acetazolamide](/wiki/Acetazolamide "Acetazolamide"), repeated drainage via
lumbar puncture, or the insertion of a shunt such as a ventriculoperitoneal
shunt.[22]

### CSF
leak[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=12
"Edit section: CSF leak")]

[CSF can leak](/wiki/Cerebrospinal_fluid_leak "Cerebrospinal fluid leak") from
the [dura](/wiki/Dura_mater "Dura mater") as a result of different causes such
as physical trauma or a lumbar puncture, or from [no known
cause](/wiki/Idiopathy "Idiopathy") when it is termed a [spontaneous
cerebrospinal fluid leak](/wiki/Spontaneous_cerebrospinal_fluid_leak
"Spontaneous cerebrospinal fluid leak").[25] It is usually associated with
[intracranial hypotension](/wiki/Intracranial_hypotension "Intracranial
hypotension"): low CSF pressure.[24] It can cause headaches, made worse by
standing, moving and coughing,[24] as the low CSF pressure causes the brain to
"sag" downwards and put pressure on its lower structures.[24] If a leak is
identified, a [beta-2 transferrin](/wiki/Beta-2_transferrin "Beta-2
transferrin") test of the leaking fluid, when positive, is highly specific and
sensitive for the detection for CSF leakage.[25] [Medical
imaging](/wiki/Medical_imaging "Medical imaging") such as CT scans and MRI
scans can be used to investigate for a presumed CSF leak when no obvious leak
is found but low CSF pressure is identified.[26] [Caffeine](/wiki/Caffeine
"Caffeine"), given either orally or [intravenously](/wiki/Intravenous
"Intravenous"), often offers symptomatic relief.[26] Treatment of an
identified leak may include injection of a person's blood into the epidural
space (an [epidural blood patch](/wiki/Epidural_blood_patch "Epidural blood
patch")), [spinal surgery](/wiki/Spinal_surgery "Spinal surgery"), or [fibrin
glue](/wiki/Fibrin_glue "Fibrin glue").[26]

### Lumbar
puncture[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=13
"Edit section: Lumbar puncture")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9f/4_vials_of_human_cerebrospinal_fluid.jpg/220px-4_vials_of_human_cerebrospinal_fluid.jpg)](/wiki/File:4_vials_of_human_cerebrospinal_fluid.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:4_vials_of_human_cerebrospinal_fluid.jpg "Enlarge")

Vials containing human cerebrospinal fluid.

Main article: [Lumbar puncture](/wiki/Lumbar_puncture "Lumbar puncture")

CSF can be tested for the diagnosis of a variety of [neurological
diseases](/wiki/Neurological_disease "Neurological disease"), usually obtained
by a procedure called [lumbar puncture](/wiki/Lumbar_puncture "Lumbar
puncture").[27] Lumbar puncture is carried out under sterile conditions by
inserting a needle into the subarachnoid space, usually between the third and
fourth [lumbar vertebrae](/wiki/Lumbar_vertebrae "Lumbar vertebrae"). CSF is
extracted through the needle, and tested.[25] About one third of people
experience a headache after lumbar puncture,[25] and pain or discomfort at the
needle entry site is common. Rarer complications may include bruising,
[meningitis](/wiki/Meningitis "Meningitis") or ongoing post lumbar-puncture
leakage of CSF.[1]

Testing often including observing the colour of the fluid, measuring CSF
pressure, and counting and identifying [white](/wiki/White_blood_cell "White
blood cell") and [red blood cells](/wiki/Red_blood_cell "Red blood cell")
within the fluid; measuring protein and glucose levels; and
[culturing](/wiki/Microbiological_culture "Microbiological culture") the
fluid.[25][27] The presence of red blood cells and
[xanthochromia](/wiki/Xanthochromia "Xanthochromia") may indicate
[subarachnoid hemorrhage](/wiki/Subarachnoid_hemorrhage "Subarachnoid
hemorrhage"); whereas [central nervous system](/wiki/Central_nervous_system
"Central nervous system") infections such as [meningitis](/wiki/Meningitis
"Meningitis"), may be indicated by elevated white blood cell levels.[27] A CSF
culture may yield the [microorganism](/wiki/Microorganism "Microorganism")
that has caused the infection,[25] or [PCR](/wiki/Polymerase_chain_reaction
"Polymerase chain reaction") may be used to identify a viral cause.[27]
Investigations to the total type and nature of proteins reveal point to
specific diseases, including [multiple sclerosis](/wiki/Multiple_sclerosis
"Multiple sclerosis"), [paraneoplastic
syndromes](/wiki/Paraneoplastic_syndrome "Paraneoplastic syndrome"), [systemic
lupus erythematosus](/wiki/Systemic_lupus_erythematosus "Systemic lupus
erythematosus"), [neurosarcoidosis](/wiki/Neurosarcoidosis
"Neurosarcoidosis"), [cerebral angiitis](/wiki/Cerebral_angiitis "Cerebral
angiitis");[1] and specific [antibodies](/wiki/Antibodies "Antibodies") such
as [Aquaporin 4](/wiki/Aquaporin_4 "Aquaporin 4") may be tested for to assist
in the diagnosis of [autoimmune](/wiki/Autoimmune "Autoimmune") conditions.[1]
A lumbar puncture that drains CSF may also be used as part of treatment for
some conditions, including [idiopathic intracranial
hypertension](/wiki/Idiopathic_intracranial_hypertension "Idiopathic
intracranial hypertension") and [normal pressure
hydrocephalus](/wiki/Normal_pressure_hydrocephalus "Normal pressure
hydrocephalus").[1]

Lumbar puncture can also be performed to measure the [intracranial
pressure](/wiki/Intracranial_pressure "Intracranial pressure"), which might be
increased in certain types of [hydrocephalus](/wiki/Hydrocephalus
"Hydrocephalus"). However, a lumbar puncture should never be performed if
increased intracranial pressure is suspected due to certain situations such as
a tumour, because it can lead to fatal [brain
herniation](/wiki/Brain_herniation "Brain herniation").[25]

### Anaesthesia and
chemotherapy[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=14
"Edit section: Anaesthesia and chemotherapy")]

See also: [Blood–cerebrospinal fluid
barrier](/wiki/Blood%E2%80%93cerebrospinal_fluid_barrier "Blood–cerebrospinal
fluid barrier")

Some [anaesthetics](/wiki/Anesthetic "Anesthetic") and
[chemotherapy](/wiki/Chemotherapy "Chemotherapy") are injected
[intrathecally](/wiki/Intrathecal "Intrathecal") into the subarachnoid space,
where they spread around CSF, meaning substances that cannot cross the [blood-
brain barrier](/wiki/Blood-brain_barrier "Blood-brain barrier") can still be
active throughout the central nervous system.[28][29]
[Baricity](/wiki/Baricity "Baricity") refers to the density of a substance
compared to the density of human cerebrospinal fluid and is used in [general
anesthesia](/wiki/General_anesthesia "General anesthesia") to determine the
manner in which a particular drug will spread in the
[intrathecal](/wiki/Intrathecal "Intrathecal") space.[28]

##
History[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: History")]

Various comments by ancient physicians have been read as referring to CSF.
[Hippocrates](/wiki/Hippocrates "Hippocrates") discussed "water" surrounding
the brain when describing congenital [hydrocephalus](/wiki/Hydrocephalus
"Hydrocephalus"), and [Galen](/wiki/Galen "Galen") referred to "excremental
liquid" in the ventricles of the brain, which he believed was purged into the
nose. But for some 16 intervening centuries of ongoing anatomical study, CSF
remained unmentioned in the literature. This is perhaps because of the
prevailing autopsy technique, which involved cutting off the head, thereby
removing evidence of CSF before the brain was examined.[30]

The modern rediscovery of CSF is now credited to [Emanuel
Swedenborg](/wiki/Emanuel_Swedenborg "Emanuel Swedenborg"). In a manuscript
written between 1741 and 1744, unpublished in his lifetime, Swedenborg
referred to CSF as "spirituous lymph" secreted from the roof of the fourth
ventricle down to the medulla oblongata and spinal cord. This manuscript was
eventually published in translation in 1887.[30]

[Albrecht von Haller](/wiki/Albrecht_von_Haller "Albrecht von Haller"), a
Swiss physician and physiologist, made note in his 1747 book on physiology
that the "water" in the brain was secreted into the ventricles and absorbed in
the veins, and when secreted in excess, could lead to hydrocephalus.[30]
[Francois Magendie](/wiki/Francois_Magendie "Francois Magendie") studied the
properties of CSF by vivisection. He discovered the foramen Magendie, the
opening in the roof of the fourth ventricle, but mistakenly believed that CSF
was secreted by the [pia mater](/wiki/Pia_mater "Pia mater").[30]

[Thomas Willis](/wiki/Thomas_Willis "Thomas Willis") (noted as the discoverer
of the [circle of Willis](/wiki/Circle_of_Willis "Circle of Willis")) made
note of the fact that the consistency of CSF is altered in meningitis.[30] In
1869 [Gustav Schwalbe](/wiki/Gustav_Schwalbe "Gustav Schwalbe") proposed that
CSF drainage could occur via lymphatic vessels.[1]

In 1891, [W. Essex Wynter](/wiki/W._Essex_Wynter "W. Essex Wynter") began
treating tubercular meningitis by tapping the subarachnoid space, and
[Heinrich Quincke](/wiki/Heinrich_Quincke "Heinrich Quincke") began to
popularize lumbar puncture, which he advocated for both diagnostic and
therapeutic purposes.[30] In 1912, a neurologist William Mestrezat gave the
first accurate description of the chemical composition of CSF.[30] In 1914,
[Harvey W. Cushing](/wiki/Harvey_W._Cushing "Harvey W. Cushing") published
conclusive evidence that CSF is secreted by the [choroid
plexus](/wiki/Choroid_plexus "Choroid plexus").[30]

## Other
animals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cerebrospinal_fluid&action=edit&section=16
"Edit section: Other animals")]

During [phylogenesis](/wiki/Phylogenesis "Phylogenesis"), CSF is present
within the [neuraxis](/wiki/Neuraxis "Neuraxis") before it circulates.[3] The
CSF of [Teleostei](/wiki/Teleostei "Teleostei") fish is contained within the
ventricles of the brains, but not in a nonexistent subarachnoid space.[3] In
mammals, where a subarachnoid space is present, CSF is present in it.[3]
Absorption of CSF is seen in [amniotes](/wiki/Amniote "Amniote") and more
complex species, and as species become progressively more complex, the system
of absorption becomes progressively more enhanced, and the role of spinal
epidural veins in absorption plays a progressively smaller and smaller
role.[3]

The amount of cerebrospinal fluid varies by size and species.[31] In humans
and other [mammals](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal"), cerebrospinal fluid, produced,
circulating, and reabsorbed in a similar manner to humans, and with a similar
function, turns over at a rate of 3–5 times a day.[31] Problems with CSF
circulation leading to hydrocephalus occur in other animals.[31]

qa.question: what is the liquid in the brain called

triviaqa_21136_166.Query Analysis: The query seeks to identify the specific liquid found within the human brain.
triviaqa_21136_166.Answer Analysis: The answer specifies that the liquid in the brain is known as 'Cerebrospinal fluid'.
triviaqa_21136_166.Document Content Analysis: The document provides detailed information about the human brain, including its composition, protection mechanisms, and various parts. It mentions the role of cerebrospinal fluid in protecting the brain.
